Both these persons were Greeks, connected, as is clear from the gentilician names they bore, with Roman families 01 distinction.

Paetus Tmasea is mentioned by Juvenal, with his son·in·law, Helvidius Priscus (S. v. 36). His character was that of an honest man in times of the worst corruption, and his affection for Persius, which the Gram- marian says lasted nearly ten years, and therefore only ended with his death (for Thrasea survived him four years), was a strong testimony to the poet's goodness. Itis said they sometimes travelled together, but we are not told where they travelled. There is no trace iu the writings of Persius of his having been out 01 Italy. Thrasea was put to death with scarcely the shadow 01 a pretext, ab. 66. The Senate condemned him under compulsion. .

Arria, the wife of Thrasea, was the daughter of Arria mentioued above, and it was for her Persius wrote the lines on her mother's death which were destroyed with his other juvenile productione. The relation· ship between Arria and Persius is not known.

His father, it appears, left a sister, and it would seem that she lived with her sister-in·law after Flaccus’ death. According to the amended text of the life Persius had an only sister. It does not appear whether his mother had any family by her second marriage. His love for these ladies and his dutiful attention to them are represented as most exem· ¹ plary, and to their society no doubt, as Jahn says, he owed much of that maidenly modesty and gentlenesa of character which the Grammarian attributes to him. That he was carefully watched and kept from tempta· tion in boyhood may be inferred from what he says to Cornutus, S. v, 32, sqq, and the same care was shown in the selection of that good man for his toacher. His father when he died left him under a ‘tutor,' whose name is not mentioned, but who there is every reason to sup·

pose discharged his trust faithfully, for Persius died rich, leaving his mother and sister between them two milliona of sesterces¹ in ready money.
